document.docTitle: A new species of Sumapazomyia Fogaça, Couri, Pérez & de Carvalho (Diptera: Muscidae) from Colombia

emphasis.docTitle:
A new species of
Sumapazomyia Fogaça, Couri, Pérez & de Carvalho
( Diptera : Muscidae ) from Colombia

subSection.paragraph: YARDANY RAMOS-PASTRANA 1* , KAREN YULIETH UNI-URREGO 1 & JOÃO M. FOGAÇA 2

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: Universidad de la Amazonia, Grupo de Investigación en Entomología Universidad de la Amazonia -GIEUA-, Laboratorio de Entomología -LEUA-, Av. 11 5–69 Juan XXIII, Florencia, Caquetá , Colombia .
Department of Zoology, Universidade Estadual do Mato Grosso , Tangará da Serra, Brazil .

subSection.paragraph:
Sumapazomyia
Fogaça et al . 2019
, is a monotypic Andean genus from the Colombian Andes. Here we described one new species of
Sumapazomyia
from Colombia , namely
Sumapazomyia quimbaya
sp. nov.
(type-locality: Risaralda , Otún, Quimbaya, Santuario de Fauna y Flora Otún Quimbaya), and an identification key to segregate the two species, including color images and illustrations of male and female terminalia is given. The distribution of the two species is mapped.

Key words:
Coenosiini
, diversity , Neotropical region , protected areas , taxonomy

Sumapazomyia
Fogaça et al . 2019
, is an Andean genus erected to include one species from the Colombian Andes,
Sumapazomyia inusitata
Fogaça et al ., 2019
, with a peculiar morphology of the head and mouthparts, which are not known among the
Muscidae (
Fogaça et al . 2019
)
.
Sumapazomyia
is a genus of the tribe Coenosiini , which includes 30 genera, some of which are distributed worldwide (
de Carvalho et al . 2005
). Species of the genus can be easy distinguished by the dichoptic male; parafacial and gena wide, eye setulose, with sparse, short and fine setulae; palpus slender, very short, length equal to length of antenna; proboscis with labellum modified and well developed, prestomal teeth reduced, and prementum shiny with a few and sparse setulae (
Fogaça et al . 2019
).

Here we described and illustrated a new species of
Sumapazomyia
from Colombia , and provide an identification key to segregate the two species and a distribution map.
Specimens. The material studied belongs to the Instituto de Investigación de Recursos Biológicos Alexander von Humboldt (IAvH), Villa de Leyva, Boyacá , Colombia .

Morphology, dissections and terminology. The total length of a specimen was measured in lateral view by summing the distances from the frons (antenna excluded) to the scutellum apex and from the scutellum apex to the abdomen apex. To study the internal morphology of the male terminalia, the abdomen apex was cut off at the third tergite, placed into lactic acid (85%), and heated at 150°C over a Thermo Scientific Cimarec plate for approximately 25 minutes ( Cumming 1992 ). The pieces were dissected and photographed in glycerin using a concave slide. After study, genitalia were stored in microvials containing glycerin. The wings were mounted on microslides with Canada balsam. The microvial and microslide were pinned along with the respective specimen. The external morphological terminology follows Cumming & Wood (2017) . The following abbreviations were used: a : anterior surface, ad : anterodorsal surface, av : anteroventral surface, cerc : cercus, d : dorsal surface, distph : distiphallus, epand : epandrium, epiph : epiphallus, epiprct : epiproct, hypd : hypandrium, hyprct : hypoproct, p : posterior surface, pd : posterodorsal surface, pgt : postgonite, phapod : phallapodeme, pregt : pregonite, pv : posteroventral surface, st : sternite, sur : surstylus, tg : tergite, and v : ventral surface.

Images and map. Photographs were taken with a Leica digital camera DFC450 coupled to a stereomicroscope Leica M205A and connected to a computer with Leica Application Suite software, with automatic mounting module (synchronization software) (http://www.syncroscopy.com/syncroscopy/). Microphotograph of the antenna were taken with a Hitachi scanning electron microscope TM4000 II. Illustrations of the terminalia were made using Infinite Painter software, using the corresponding digital images. The map showing geographic records of the two species was plotted using the SimpleMappr software ( Shorthouse 2010 ).

Labels. In the list of the examined material, label data are given as presented on the labels. The square brackets ([…]) are used to indicate complementary data that are not present in the specimen labels. Data for specimens with identical data were simplified with idem and only the data that differ from the anterior labels were written; the slash “/” separates data from each label.

bibRefCitation.author: Fogaca, J. M. & Couri, M. S. & Perez, S. & de Carvalho, C. J. B.
bibRefCitation.refString: Fogaca, J. M., Couri, M. S., Perez, S. & de Carvalho, C. J. B. (2019) A remarkable new Coenosiini genus (Diptera, Muscidae). Zootaxa, 4608 (2), 380 - 388. https: // doi. org / 10.11646 / zootaxa. 4608.2.12

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type species:
Sumapazomyia inusitata
Fogaça et al . 2019
, by original designation.

heading.emphasis:
Key to species of
Sumapazomyia Fogaça, Couri, Pérez & de Carvalho

subSubSection.paragraph: Diagnosis. Male. Six pairs of frontal setae; postpedicel 2x the length of pedicel; proepisternum with two long, stout and black setae; proepimeron with a row of three setae, the central one stout and the longest, anepisternum setulose near notopleuron and anepimeron; sternite 5 with two long, stout and brown setae in the lobes; cercus with lateral margins slightly straight, hypandrium with upper anterior margin sinuous, with margins slightly straight; epiphallus straight.
Measurements Male. Body length: 7 mm ( holotype ).

Description. Coloration. Ground color grey. Frons and fronto-orbital plate dark brown. Parafacial and gena with silvery pruinosity. Ocellar triangle dark brown. Antenna, arista and palpus dark brown. Mesonotum brown. Pleurae grey. Calypter whitish. Halter yellowish. Wing light brown. All legs grey to brown. Abdomen brown with lateral grey pruinosity of all tergites.

Thorax ( Figs 1, 4 ). Postpronotal lobe, presutural scutum and scutellum with a few setulae. Acrostichal setae 1+3, setae differentiated from covering setulae; intralar setae 1+2; basal postpronatal setae 2; supra-alar setae 1+1; intrapostalar seta developed. Notopleuron with 2 similar setae, without cilia covering it. Scutellum with sub-basal and an apical pair of stout setae. Prosternum bare, proepisternum with two long, stout and black setae; proepimeron with a row of three setae, the central longest and stout, anepisternum setulose near notopleuron and anepimeron; anepimeron bare; katepisternum setae 1+1+1; katepimeron bare; meron bare.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1–6.
Sumapazomyia quimbaya Ramos-Pastrana, Uni-Urrego & Fogaça
sp. nov.
(IAvH-E 223999). Male. 1 , Habitus, left lateral view; 2 , Detail of head, left lateral view; 3 , Detail of head, frontal view; 4 , Thorax, dorsal view; 5 , Wing; 6 , Abdomen, dorsal view.

subSubSection.paragraph: Wing ( Fig. 5 ) length 5.9 mm . Long, slender, anal lobe weakly developed. Vein R 4+5 and M 1 slightly curved downwards and parallel on apical part; vein dm-cu almost straight; vein CuA 2 +A 1 short; vein A 2 long and inconspicuous.

Legs ( Fig. 1 ). Fore coxa with two rows of long, stout and black setae ventrally. Fore femur with d , pv , p and pd complete rows of setae and v only in basal half. Fore tibia with one long, stout, erect and black setae pd and one apically pd about 1/2 as long as postpedicel. Mid coxa with a row of long, stout and black setae in lower margin (the rest of the leg lost). Hind coxa with rows in the anterior and posterior margins basally. Hind femur with irregular ad , av , v and pv rows of setae, longer on basal half. Hind tibia with irregular ad , av , v , d and pv rows of setae and two apical setae ( av and v ).
Female ( Figs 14–17 ) (n= 2). Body length 6.7–7.7 mm . Similar to male, only differing in the where the gray pruinosity is less on the scutum, scutellum and abdomen.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 14–17.
Sumapazomyia quimbaya Ramos-Pastrana, Uni-Urrego & Fogaça
sp. nov.
(IAvH-E 224029). Female. 14 , Habitus, left lateral view; 15 , Terminalia lateral view; 16 , Terminalia dorsal view; 17 , Terminalia ventral view.

FIGURE 18. Geographical records of
Sumapazomyia quimbaya Ramos-Pastrana, Uni-Urrego & Fogaça
sp. nov.
and
Sumapazomyia inusitata
.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type material.
HOLOTYPE ♂ : COLOMBIA ,
Risaralda
, SFF [Santuario de Fauna y Flora] Otún Quimbaya , Cuchilla camino, 04º44′N / 75º35′W ,
1960 m
[eters],
19.VI–7.VII.2003
, Trampa Malaise , López, G. Leg. ( 1 ♂ IAvH- E 223999) (photographed specimen)
.
PARATYPES : idem ( 1 ♀ IAvH-E 224029) (photographed specimen) / idem
Cundinamarca
, PNN [Parque Nacional Natural] Chingaza , Alto de la mina pedregal, 04º31′N / 73º45′W ,
3610 m
[eters],
13–27.VIII.2003
, Trampa Malaise, E . Niño Leg. ( 1 ♀ IAvH-E 224062)
.

Etymology.
Sumapazomyia quimbaya
sp. nov.
is named after the acronym for the Santuario de Fauna y Flora Otún Quimbaya, name of type locality. Treated as a noun in apposition.

Geographical distribution.
Colombia ( Cundinamarca , Risaralda ) ( Fig. 18 )
.

Habitat. Specimens were collected in the Otún Quimbaya Flora and Fauna Sanctuary, where the vegetation is composed of Andean cloud forests of the Western Cordillera and the Chingaza National Natural Park with frailejon vegetation typical of the paramo of the Andean region in the Central Cordillera of Colombia ( Serna, 2018 ), the same locality where the type species of
Sumapazomyia
,
S . inusitata
, was collected, thus indicating that
Sumapazomyia
is possibly well distributed throughout the Colombian Andean Region.

subSection.paragraph: To Dr. Jhon Cesar Neita, curator of the collections of Instituto de Investigación de Recursos Biológicos Alexander von Humboldt (IAvH), Villa de Leyva, Boyacá , Colombia , for the loan of the specimens and to the biologist Eric Córdoba-Suarez for his support.
